thread.title: Axl Rose‚Äôs surprise move in Brisbane
thread.title_full: Axl Rose‚Äôs surprise move in Brisbane

author: Belinda Seeney
title: Axl Rose‚Äôs surprise move in Brisbane
text:
US rockers Guns N‚Äô Roses screamed on to stage last night to the deafening roar of more than 40,000 local fans who had waited 32 years to see the iconic line-up of singer Axl Rose, guitarist Slash, bass player Duff McKagan and longtime keyboardist Dizzy Reed play Brisbane.
If there was any doubt to whether the band could still cut it as a live act - Rose turned 55 on Monday and McKagan 53 the day before - they were put firmly to rest.
One surprise though was Rose himself - the rocker was uncharacteristically subdued, keeping his banter and audience interaction to a minimum, preferring to let the music do the talking.
The iconic Slash in his first time playing Brisbane with Guns N‚Äô Roses. Picture: Marc Robertson Source: News Corp Australia
The band hit the stage at 7.50pm, 20 minutes later than the scheduled 7.30pm start, possibly to accommodate a sea of patrons stuck in lengthy queues, first to collect tickets then wristbands for those in floor seats.
Rose‚Äôs distinctive wail rang true throughout the suburban stadium as he prowled the stage; dancing, running and climbing atop speakers.
Slash‚Äôs signature guitar work was a delight.
An epic freestyle solo halfway through the show where he was briefly joined by other band members clocked in a shade under nine minutes.
Axl Rose and Slash in full flight as Guns N‚Äô Roses play QSAC in Brisbane. Picture: Marc Robertson Source: News Corp Australia
McKagan‚Äôs solid and distinctive bass lines punctuated the two-and-a-half hour set and he also lent his vocal stylings to a cover of The Damned‚Äôs New Rose.
He paid homage to the late Lemmy Kilmister of Motorhead, wearing a t-shirt emblazoned with his face, and Prince, sporting a hand-drawn purple ‚Äúlovesymbol‚Äù on his bass.
This was an act at the top of its game: there was not a musical misfire to be heard and the tight, high energy production would have been the envy of musicians half the age.
The concert at Nathan‚Äôs Queensland Sports and Athletic Centre (QSAC) kicked off the Australian leg of the band‚Äôs Not In This Lifetime tour and marked the first time the original band members had played Brisbane.
GOOD F'N NIGHT BRISBANE!
THANK YOU üá¶üá∫
‚Äî Guns N' Roses (@gunsnroses) February 7, 2017 The setlist drew from four of Guns N‚Äô Roses‚Äôs five studio albums ‚Äî tracks from 1993‚Äôs The Spaghetti Incident? were absent ‚Äî as well as 2010‚Äôs controversial Chinese Democracy, released by Rose 15 years after the band broke up.
With the well-publicised split behind them, last night‚Äôs show demonstrated how Guns N‚Äô Roses became one of the biggest rock bands of the past century.
Kicking off with It‚Äôs So Easy and Mr Brownstone from the band‚Äôs debut album, Appetite for Destruction, the Gunners launched into Chinese Democracy before unleashing the frenetic Welcome to the Jungle on an appreciative crowd.
The setlist was a mix of classic hits, covers and fan favourites including Sweet Child O‚Äô Mine, November Rain, Civil War, a cover of Wings‚Äô Live and Let Die and an instrumental mash-up of Pink Floyd‚Äôs Wish You Were Here with Eric Clapton‚Äôs Layla.
The gig ended in flurry of fireworks, confetti canons and the frenetic strains of Paradise City.
While last night was the first Brisbane concert featuring the group‚Äôs original members, frontman Rose brought a collective of musicians under the Guns N‚Äô Roses umbrella to town in 2007 for his Chinese Democracy tour.
Axl Rose belts out a number out front of Guns N‚Äô Roses. Picture: Marc Robertson Source: News Corp Australia
GNR in Brisbane
Originally published as Axl Rose‚Äôs surprise move in Brisbane
